children.name: warn b1
children.definition: warnto tell sb that sth bad or dangerous may happen, so that they can avoid it or prevent it :
examples: ‘be careful, the rocks are slippery,’ alex warned.
warn somebody about somethingespecially spoken
travellers to africa are being warned about the danger of hiv infection.
warn (somebody) of somethingespecially written
salmon farmers are warning of the severe crisis facing the industry.
warn somebody (not) to do something
i warned you not to walk home alone.
motorists are being warned to avoid the centre of london this weekend.
warn sb against doing sth
tourists are warned against going to remoter regions.
we tried to warn her, but she refused to listen.
the consequences could be serious - i just wanted to warn you.
warn (that)
the local people were warned that the volcano might erupt at any time.
we were warned there were going to be delays on the motorway, so we came back by a different route.
we warned them that there was a bull in the field.

children.name: give sb a warning b1
children.definition: give sb a warning to tell someone that if they continue to behave in an unsatisfactory way, they will be punished:
examples: ▪ so you’ve given her a warning about her conduct in future?
give sb a warning that
▪ the us gave a warning that, if the hostages were not released, they would be forced to take military action.
give sb a final warning
▪ one day monica’s boss gave her a final warning. if she messed up again, she was fired.

children.name: caution c2
children.definition: caution formal to warn someone not to do something because it is likely to be dangerous or have a bad result:
examples: ‘be careful now,’ sarah cautioned. ‘don’t do anything stupid.’
caution (sb) that
officials were quick to caution that these remarks did not mean an end to the peace process.
caution (sb) against
marshall cautioned against pouring millions of pounds into taking legal action when there was no guarantee of victory.
business leaders are cautioning against hasty action that would hamper flexibility.
the policeman cautioned the children against talking to strangers.
caution sb to do sth
he cautioned them to avoid the forest at night.

children.name: tip off c2
children.definition: tip off to warn sb about sth that is going to happen, especially to warn the police about a crime, so that they can try to prevent it: báo trước (bí mật)
examples: someone must have tipped the press off about the princess’s visit.
a farmer noticed our foreign accents and tipped off the security police.
tip sb off that
his contact had not merely tipped him off that drugs were on the premises, he had told him where to look.
be tipped off about
the police had been tipped off about the gang’s arrival.be tipped off that
customs officers had been tipped off that the drugs were hidden in a child’s rucksack.

children.name: alert c2
children.definition: alert to officially or publicly warn people of possible danger so that they can be ready to deal with it: cảnh báo
examples: when he realized that one engine was not working, the pilot alerted air traffic control.
an anonymous letter alerted policetothe possibility of a terrorist attack at the airport.
alert sb that
drivers are being alerted that an escaped prisoner has been seen hitch-hiking on the road to frankfurt.
alert sb to sth
a poster campaign to alert people to the disease

children.name: raise the alarm c2
children.definition: sound/raise the alarm to warn everyone about sth bad or dangerous that is already happening so that they can take action to stop it or avoid it: báo động (đang xảy ra)
examples: leighton was told to stand at the door, and to raise the alarm if a guard came.
sound/raise the alarm about
the red cross has sounded the alarm about the danger of further famine in the region.
the problem is that if you sound the alarm about fraud in your company, you might end up out of a job.
a local doctor was the first to raise the alarm about this latest virus.

children.name: forewarn x
children.definition: forewarn formal to warn someone about something bad that is going to happen soon, so that they have enough time to prepare for it:
examples: barry hearn forewarned me that the meeting was going to be tough.
we had been forewarned that the roads weren’t very good.
be forewarned of sth
a police team, forewarned of the raid, had taken up positions inside the bank.

children.name: warn off b1
children.definition: warn off to try to prevent sb from doing sth by warning them about the trouble or problems it could cause for them: cảnh báo
examples: the army had put signs up around the area where the mines were, to warn people off
the female rattlesnake warns off intruders by making a loud noise.
some animals mark their territory to warn off rivals.
warn sb off (doing) sthespecially british englishto tell someone that they should not do or use something because it might be dangerous :
doctors should have warned people off using the drug much earlier than they did.
even though we’d been warned off going into the mountains, we couldn’t resist it.

children.name: warning b1
children.definition: warning
examples: 1[c or u] something, especially a statement, that tells you that something bad, dangerous, or annoying might happen so that you can be ready or avoid it
warning of
a warning of floods
warning about
warnings about the dangers of smoking
warning against
this experience should serve as a warning against complacency.
warning to
a warning to pregnant women not to drink alcohol
awarning thatgrey squirrels are threatening the existence of red squirrels
2[c] a statement telling someone that if they continue to behave in an unsatisfactory way, they will be punished :
the surrey team weregivenawarninglast year for repeated offences.
i’m giving you afinal warning– don’t be late again.
written/verbal warning
give a warninghe slammed on the brakes without giving any warning.
issue a warning(= officially warn people )the government issued a warning about eating raw eggs.
deliver/sound a warning(= give a public warning )the chairman sounded a warning that jobs could be lost.
heed a warning(= take notice of it )drivers failed to heed warnings about fog.
ignore a warninghe had ignored their warning to stay in the car.
advance/prior warningworkers were given no advance warning of the closure.
fair warninghe was given fair warning that such behaviour would not be tolerated.
a stern warningi got a stern warning against giving false information to the police.
a stark warningcigarette packets carry the stark warning ‘smoking kills’.
a health warning(= a warning that something is bad for your health )all tobacco products must carry a health warning.
a flood/gale/tornado warninga flood warning has been issued for the river wye in herefordshire.
without (any) warningpolice fired into the crowd without warning.
a word of warning(= used before telling someone to be careful about something )a word of warning: don’t use too much glue.

children.name: tip-off x
children.definition: tip-off a warning that something bad is going to happen, especially a warning about a crime that is given to the police in time for them to stop it happening:
examples: ▪ police were called to the hotel after a tip-off.
acting on a tip-offdoing something because of a tip-off
▪ acting on a tip-off, customs officers seized 50 kilos of cocaine from a house in leicester.

children.name: caution x
children.definition: caution formal a warning to someone about a possible danger, especially a warning added to the end of a statement or piece of information:
examples: this caution cannot be overstated: if the belts are incorrectly adjusted they are useless.
caution: do not install electrical equipment near or around water sources.
although pleased, henson added a caution that the team still has a long way to go.
word/note of caution
a final word of caution – never try any of this without backing up your system.

children.name: spoken: when you want to warn sb
beware c1
children.definition: beware especiallywrittenused to warn people about sth dangerous - usually seen on signs and official statements: cảnh giác, coi chừng
examples: ▪ beware. deep water.
beware of
▪ beware of the dog.
▪ beware of falling rocks.
▪ the police warn tourists to beware of pickpockets, especially in crowded places.
beware of doing sth
▪ beware of accidentally starting the engine while you are cleaning the blades.

children.name: look out b1
children.definition: look out/watch outb2 spoken say this to urgently warn someone that they will have an accident if they do not immediately try to avoid it:
examples: look out! there’s a train coming!
watch out! you nearly hit that car.
look out! there's a car coming!

children.name: mind b1
children.definition: mind ukspokenuse this to warn someone not totouchsomething ordosomething that would be dangerous or cause trouble:
examples: ▪ mind the table charlotte, there are drinks on it.
mind/mind out
▪ mind! the plate’s hot.
▪ mind out! there’s a motorcycle!
mind you don’t do sth
▪ the cat’s down there - mind you don’t tread on him.
mind how you goused to warn sb to walk carefully to avoid slipping or falling
▪ mind how you go. the path’s a bit slippery.

children.name: watch out b2
children.definition: watch out/watch itspoken use this to warn sb that what they are doing could be dangerous:
examples: ‘watch out!’ yelled the driver, as the truck veered towards his car
watch it! you nearly knocked my head off with that ladder.
"watch out!" he shouted, but it was too late – she had knocked the whole tray of drinks on the floor.

children.name: be careful a2
children.definition: be careful spoken use this to warn sb that what they are doing could be dangerous:
examples: i handed phil the heavy revolver. ‘be careful, it’s loaded.’
be careful, it’s very hot.
be careful with
hey! be careful with that cigarette!
be careful/ take care not to do sth
be careful not to do anything that might make him angry.

children.name: you’d better a2
children.definition: you’d betterspoken informal use this to warn or advise sb that they should do something in order to avoid trouble:
examples: ▪ ‘i suppose i ought to apologize.’ ‘yes, you’d better, or she might make things difficult for you.
you’d better do sth
▪ you’d better tell the police in case they think it was your fault.
▪ the train leaves in twenty minutes, so you’d better hurry up!

children.name: sth ends in tears x
children.definition: sth ends in tearsbritish spoken say this to warn sb that sth they are determined to do is not sensible and will probably end badly:
examples: ▪ never have an affair with a work colleague - they usually end in tears.
it’ll (all) end in tears
▪ my common sense told me: ‘stay away! it’ll end in tears!’

children.name: making you realize that sth bad could happen
warning x
children.definition: warning  intended to or likely to warn you that something bad will happen if you continue to do something or do not do something: nhằm cảnh báo
examples: red warning lights were flashing.
a warning signdon’t ignore the warning signs of stress.
a warning shottroops fired warning shots over the heads of demonstrators.
a warning lightred warning lights were flashing.
a warning look/glanceshe gave me a warning look, but i carried on.
a warning gesturehe put his finger to his lips in a warning gesture.

children.name: be a warning b1
children.definition: be a warning/biː ə ˈwɔːʳnɪŋ/  if an event or factis a warning,it shows that something bad could happen or is going to happen:
examples: ▪ the story of the titanic is a warning to anyone who trusts too much in their technology.
▪ the only warning was a low rumbling sound.
be a warning of
▪ pain in the shoulder and arm can be a warning of a heart attack.

children.name: set alarm bells ringing x
children.definition: set (the) alarm bells ringing if somethingsets (the) alarm bells ringingit makes you realize that sth seriously wrong or very dangerous is happening: hồi chuông cảnh báo
examples: there were no lights on when i got home. that immediately set alarm bells ringing.
a brief study of the company’s accounts set the alarm bells ringing -- there was no trace of the $56 million loan.

children.name: warn b1
children.definition: warn
examples: warn sb (that)
something warned lucy that she must stop him.
the bleached bones of cattle warn the traveler how hot it can be in death valley.
warn of
dark clouds warned of the approaching storm.

children.name: cautionary x
children.definition: cautionary providing a warning of something bad that could happen or a warning against particular actions or behaviour: cảnh báo
examples: cautionary note/comment/words etc
the director ended her speech on a cautionary note, when she said that next year would be even harder than this year.
most observers were optimistic, yet somesoundedacautionary note.
cautionary tale(= the story of an event that is used to warn people )
a cautionary tale about how not to buy a computer
the rise and fall of this company is a cautionary tale for anyone investing in the property market.

children.name: warn b1
children.definition: warnto tell sb about sth before it happens so that they are not worried or surprised by it : báo trước
examples: warn sb (that)
warn her you’re going to be back late.
registerin everyday english, people often use the expressionletsomeoneknowrather thanwarnsomeone:
let me knowif you’re not going to finish on time.

children.name: alarm b1
children.definition: alarmnounwarning còi báo động; chuông báo động; thiết bị báo động
examples: [ c ] a device which makes a loud noise to warn of danger

children.name: alert c1
children.definition: alertnounlệnh báo nguysự báo động, sựbáo nguy, lệnh báo động,
examples: a warning to people to be prepared to deal with something dangerous
_abombalert
_the army wasput on (full)alert as the peace talks began to fail.
_the public were warned to beon thealertfor(= watching carefully for) suspicious packages.

children.name: siren c2
children.definition: sirennoundevice còi tầm, còi báo động
examples: a device for making a loud warning noise
_police sirens
_when the air raid siren went off people ran to their shelters.

children.name: i told you ! c2
children.definition: i told you!/i told you so! spoken say this when you had warned someone about a possible danger that has now happened, especially if they ignored your warning:
examples: ▪ i told you he had a violent temper! why did you argue with him?
▪ i told you so! it was obvious she was going to disappear as soon as she got the money.
▪ i hate to say ‘i told you so’, but maybe you should listen to me next time.
